## Władysław Reymont: Biography and Background

Władysław Stanisław Reymont was born on May 7, 1867, in Kobiele Wielkie, near Radom, Poland, in the Russian Empire. Born into an impoverished noble family, Reymont was educated to become a master tailor, but instead worked as a gateman at a railway station and then as an actor in a troupe. He never completed his schooling but was at various times in his youth a shop apprentice, a lay brother in a monastery, a railway official, and an actor.

In 1900 he was awarded 40,000 rubles in compensation from the Warsaw-Vienna Railway after an accident in which Reymont was severely injured. In 1900, Reymont was severely injured in a railway accident, which halted his writing career until 1904 when he published the first part of Chłopi.

## "Chłopi" (The Peasants): Writing and Publication Timeline

The Peasants (Polish: Chłopi) is a novel written by the Polish author Władysław Reymont in four parts between 1904 and 1909. He started writing it in 1897, but because of a railway accident and health problems, it took seven years to complete. 

The first parts of the story were published in the weekly magazine Tygodnik Illustrowany. The novel was published in serial form in "Tygodnik Ilustrowany" from 1902–1908 and published as books from 1904–1909 in Warsaw by "Gebethner i Wolff".

## The Novel's Content and Setting

The four-volume novel The Peasants (1904–09) is a chronicle of peasant life during the four seasons of a year. He set the action in Lipce, a real village which he came to know during his work on the railway near Skierniewice, and restricted the time of events to ten months in the unspecified "now" of the 19th century.

In Chłopi, Reymont created a more complete and suggestive picture of country life than any other Polish writer. The novel impresses the reader with its authenticity of the material reality, customs, behaviour and spiritual culture of the people.

## Literary Recognition and Nobel Prize

Władysław Reymont received the 1924 Nobel Prize in Literature for this work. The Polish writer Władysław Reymont is remembered especially for his epic novel Chłopi (The Peasants), a blend of naturalism and realism written almost entirely in rural dialect. It has been translated into many languages and won for Reymont the Nobel prize for literature in 1924.

The novel has been translated into at least 27 languages. Reymont died on Dec. 5, 1925, in Warsaw.

## Other Notable Works

Before "Chłopi," Reymont's first successful and widely praised novel was The Promised Land from 1899, which brought attention to the bewildering social inequalities, poverty, conflictive multiculturalism and labour exploitation in the industrial city of Łódź (Lodz).
